Air quality data represents concentrations of O3, NO2 and NH3 measured during the period 15.05-15.10 (monthly exposure) of years 2011 and 2012 in 11 plots in Bucegi-Piatra Craiului LTER site. The pollutants were monitored using Ogawa passive samplers (www.ogawausa.com). Chemical analysis of passive samplers was performed at ICAS Campulung Moldovenesc laboratory, using ion-chromatography for ozone determination and colorimetry for NO2 and NH3.Atmospheric depositions were measured during the whole period (2011-2012) in 6 plots. Precipitations were collected inside the forest (throughfall) using 8 collectors and in open field using 2 collectors. Soil solution was monitored in 2 plots, using the profile method, with collectors placed at 10, 20, 40 and 60 cm depth (2 replicates). The reported parameters are: pH (determined by potentiometry), conductivity (conductimetry), nitrite in NH4 and inNH3 (water ion-chromatography) and alkalinity (titrimetric determination). All chemical analysis were performed by ICAS Campulung Moldovenesc laboratory following the methodology described in ICP Forests Manual (http://www.icp-forests.org/pdf/FINAL_Depo.pdf; http://www.icp-forests.org/pdf/FINAL_SoilSol.pdf)

Data on tree and stand parameters (mean diameter and height of trees, tree density, basal area and tree volume per hectare) as well as crown defoliation were available from the permanent observation stands. A three-stage sampling pattern was used for the collection of the field material: (i)                  sampling of the research stands; (ii)                sampling of the circular plots within each research stand; (iii)         sampling of the trees for more detailed measurements of tree crown parameters and tree ring analysis. Each pine stand included 12 circular sample plots distributed systematically in a grid system with on average 15-20 trees in each plot, i.e.; about 150-250 sample trees per stand. There, tree stem diameter was permanently measured and crown defoliation assessed for all sample trees annually. In addition three closest to the centre of sampling plot trees were sampled for measurement of crown parameters (height, diameter and length) and analysis of annual radial increment (tree ring width). Standard dendrochronological technique was used to assess tree growth rates. Radial growth was assessed by measuring the width of annual rings in stem cores. Each ring was measured to the closest 0.01 mm using an electronic transducer and binocular scope fixed over the moving stage. Based on the ring widths and measured diameter we computed stem basal area increment (BAI). For each of the POS a BAI chronology was computed by averaging the BAI for each year across all trees sampled at POS. Crown defoliation was assessed at the end of August. Forest monitoring methodology was employed to assess tree defoliation: healthy trees – (defoliation up to 10%); slightly damaged trees (defoliation ranging from 11 to 25%); moderately damaged trees (defoliation 26–60%); severely damaged trees (defoliation 61–99%); dead trees (defoliation 100%) (UN-ECE, 1994).

20 stands were located in the surroundings of Integrated monitoring stations (IMS) established there, and were selected according to stand maturity: 4 sapling stands (45–50 years), 4 middle aged stands (61–80 years), 4 premature stands (81–100 years), 3 mature stands (101– 120 years) and 5 over mature stands more than121 years). Data on tree and stand parameters (mean diameter and height of trees, tree density, basal area and tree volume per hectare) as well as crown defoliation were available from the permanent observation stands. A three-stage sampling pattern was used for the collection of the field material: (i)                  sampling of the research stands; (ii)                sampling of the circular plots within each research stand; (iii)         sampling of the trees for more detailed measurements of tree crown parameters and tree ring analysis. Each pine stand included 12 circular sample plots distributed systematically in a grid system with on average 15-20 trees in each plot, i.e.; about 150-250 sample trees per stand. There, tree stem diameter was permanently measured and crown defoliation assessed for all sample trees annually. In addition three closest to the centre of sampling plot trees were sampled for measurement of crown parameters (height, diameter and length) and analysis of annual radial increment (tree ring width). Standard dendrochronological technique was used to assess tree growth rates. Radial growth was assessed by measuring the width of annual rings in stem cores. Each ring was measured to the closest 0.01 mm using an electronic transducer and binocular scope fixed over the moving stage. Based on the ring widths and measured diameter we computed stem basal area increment (BAI). For each of the POS a BAI chronology was computed by averaging the BAI for each year across all trees sampled at POS. Crown defoliation was assessed at the end of August. Forest monitoring methodology was employed to assess tree defoliation: healthy trees – (defoliation up to 10%); slightly damaged trees (defoliation ranging from 11 to 25%); moderately damaged trees (defoliation 26–60%); severely damaged trees (defoliation 61–99%); dead trees (defoliation 100%) (UN-ECE, 1994).

The sampling units are not contiguous; they are placed as far apart as possible within the Level II plot in order to minimize spatial correlation between the sampling units. All measures of the sampling units are taken according to the slope. To achieve a statistical representativeness, probability sampling methods are adopted (random, systematic, stratification). Location of sampling unit excludes major heterogeneities at any scale of sampling (boulders and cliffs, tracks and paths, fire places, streams and ponds, ditches and channels, peaty pools). Biomass of vegetation and LAI of grasslands in Orgovány LTER (KISKUN LTER)

The aim of the yearly biomass and LAI measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

Biomass and LAI in grasslands was measured by harvesting all herbs and plant material over a small parcel of 0.25 m2. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight.From the dried material three fractions were separated: (1) plant material which was dead in the time of clipping, (2) non-photosynthesising living material, and (3) photosynthesising material. Biomass was calculated by summing up the dry weight of all living material, and expressed in grams / m2. For LAI measurement, the photosynthesising material was separated into groups consisting parts of seemingly similar morphology, and therefore specific leaf area (SLA). Then, the groups are weighted, and subsamples of known weights are taken for area measurement, applying high resolution scanner. Calculation of SLA and LAI: The subsamples of known weight and area provide the SLA in m2 / grams for the morphology groups, and the total area of the groups can be calculated by multiplying their SLA and weight. Sum of the areas of the morphology groups divided by the area of sampling unit provides LAI in m2 / m2.

Number of plant species: The aboveground biomass of vascular plants are removed from 0.5 x 0.5 m quadrats for biomass and LAI measurements. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight. After drying, the photosynthesizing vascular plant material seemingly living at time of cutting (i.e. the dry green material) are separated by species. The species samples are weighed separately at precision of 0.01 grams, the number of species counted. Within habitat diversity: Shannon'H is calculated from vascular plant species dried living biomass data. For one quadrat: m(i) is mass of i-th species, M is total mass, n is number of species, Shannon's H = -SUM(i=1 to n)[(m(i)/M)*log2(m(i)/M)] Number and type of layers: Visual observation. Presence and type of management: Visual observation. Presence of natural disturbances: Visual observation. Aboveground biomass by indirect methods: Spectroradiometry using CROPCSAN spectroradiometer before sampling for BIOMASS. Aboveground plant biomass measurement, see above. Calculation of NDVI for each measurements: (NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED); Application of linear regression between BIOMASS and NDVI data measured in the same quadrats. Presence of groundwater table: Expert decision. Quality of drought susceptibility: Expert decision.

The method consists in the provision of fishing gear (creels) in homogeneously distributed environments in the sampling station. The number of creels to provide depend on each sampling station. In general, it will have as many creels as possible at a distance of not less than 5 meters between them, with a maximum of five. For the selected stations that relate later, creels are arranged in three groups of three creels each, separate creels in at least five meters and groups in at least 50 meters. Each group of creels is considered one unit of effort.Creels should be type Shrimp double death with mesh size of 4 mm., Sailing simple and approximate length of 3 m., 1:1 ratio between the candle and the body of the creel.Be placed on the ground, leaving part of the cod always above the water surface. The ring must be input, however, submerged as possible and at least the mouth must always be below the water surface. This arrangement minimizes the creelential effects on birds swimmers and decreases mortality of amphibians and reptiles caught in them.The review will take place between 12 and 24 hours of operation, and has remained at least one night on business.The provision on the ground will be supported on macoyas own vegetation or wetland or lake shore, using these elements to raise the cod and allow ventilation of creels.The withdrawal of the samples was made ​​by nasa, scoring in each case the crab specimens caught mention of the following parameters: a) total length, b) carapace width (of the first 20 copies),c) carapace length (of the first 20 copies), d) sex, e) sexual stage (I or II) and f) specific comments. To each creel is measured weight crabs assembly contained therein by the use of a Pesola. When the sample obtained more than 100 copies will bypass the steps a, b, c, d and e in the copies of the creel after the one containing the copy number 100, it being necessary to measure the remaining copies of the creel in which it is located .Log the data on catches of other specimens of any species, even without specific protocol for them.

The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers data about bees trapped within 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. The trapping is done with combined flight traps (combination of yellow pan trap and transparent perspexes) placed at ecotones (transition zone between arable fields and semi-natural habitats) in May-June and August-September each year.

One trap / km² is placed at the border (ecotone) between semi-natural habitat and arable field (16 traps / site of 4x4 km). Traps consist of a yellow funnel (diameter: 25 cm) and two crossed perspex windows on top of the funnel. Trapped insects will fall in the funnel which is filled with water containing a preservative (Parmetol K 40; 0.5%). Traps are installed with a wooden frame at a height of about one m above ground. Operating schedule (emptying interval 14 days): Start at week 2–7 after full bloom of Taraxacum officinale (phenological indicator), usually in our region end of April or beginning of May; 4x emptying until end of June, then stop for 6 weeks and start again until end of September. Insects are sorted in the laboratory and sent to a specialist for determination. Frequency: yearly

LAI was assessed by indirect optical method using LAI-2000 instrument. Crown transparency and defoliation was assessed only for Q. petraea and Q. cerris trees according to the ICP Forest Manual. Stand-level mean starting and finishing days of leaf expansion and leaf shedding were determined indirectly by above- and below-canopy positioned PPFD sensors.

LAI measuements: LiCor LAI-2000 intrument. Crown health status: visual observation, ICP Forest manual. Leaf expansion and leaf shedding: Hobo Micro Station with PPFD sensor (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, USA)

LAI-measurement was done along 10x10m sampling grid in the LTER site's 1 ha permanent plot in August 2012. As a total 81 sampling points were used, each measured in triplicate. All measurements were averaged to calculate mean LAI in 2012. Crown transparency and defoliation were assessed according to the ICP Forest Manual for all Quercus petraea and Q. cerris trees in the 'A' subplot (50x50m) of the LTER site's 1 ha permanent plot. Tree-by-tree assesment was done for all Q. petraea (59 ind.) and Q. cerris (13 ind.) trees of the subplot. Starting and finishing days of leaf exansion and leaf sheding were determined comparing daily sum of above- and below-canopy PPFD. Above-canopy PPFD was measured on the top of the site's own meteorological tower at 25m. Below-canopy PPFD sensor was set ~10m from the meteorological tower at 2m. Both sensors was set to 10 min sampling interval. For characterizing actual canopy status mean PPFDbelow/PPFDabove between DOYs 0-70 was considered as 'no canopy' status and PPFDbelow/PPFDabove between DOYs 150-250 was considered as 'full canopy' status. Reaching one of the above values was considered as starting or finishing of leaf exansion or leaf sheding, respectively.

Analysis of annual tree increment by tree rings and calculation of dry weight change by allometry equations. Assessment of total litter production by litter traps.
Tree rings: increment borer, digital scanner, ImageJ image analyses software. Litterfall: litter traps.

Stand-level biomass increment was assessed by tree ring analyses. In 2011 130 Q. petraea and 99 Q. cerris samples were analyzed. In 2012 19-19 Q. petraea and Q. cerris samples were analyzed. All samples were collected in the permanent 1 hectare plot of the LTER site. Mean tree ring widths were used in allometry equations to calculate aboveground biomass change tree-by-tree and sum up to stand level using tree inventory of the site. Yearly increments were corrected by tree mortality data. Litterfall was assessed in 2012 using 25 litter traps representing the permanent hectare of the site, with 5.11 m2 total area and transformed to kg/ha.

Fluorimetric determination after particulate sample concentration by vacuum filtration and extraction in 90% acetone according to Holm – Hansen et al. (1965) and Lorenzen and Jeffrey (1980). Samples were filtered on Whatmann GF/F filters (diameter 47 mm, nominal porosity 0.7 μm) which were stored frozen (-20°C) until laboratory analysis. In order to assess precision and accuracy of measurements, on a regular basis, analytical and field precision measurements are carried out, based on the analysis of replicate samples and, with the aim of testing the accuracy, the laboratory participates to international intercalibration tests (QUASIMEME).

The time series station C1 ( Latitude 45°42'2.99N Longitude 13°42'36.00E), located in the Gulf of Trieste in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea, is part of the Adriatic Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) site . It is a shallow coastal station (17 m depth) located at 0.2 Km from the coast, at the outer border of the Natural Marine Reserve of Miramare , Trieste.
